issues.text: Whether Section 9 of the Punjab Security of State Act, 1953 is violative of Article 19(1)(a) of the Constitution

anchor.surface_text: In this Court Shri S. C. Agarwal questioned the vires of S. 9 of the Act, contending that this section is violative of the fundamental right guaranteed by Art. 19 1 a of the Constitution. No doubt, this point was not raised in the High Court

anchor.surface_text: rejecting the appellant revision petition under ss. 430 and 561-A of the Code of Criminal Procedure. issues.text: Whether prima facie the appellant's speech amounts to an offence under Section 9 of the Act

holdings.text: Section 9 of the Punjab Security of State Act clearly falls within the express language of Article 19(2) of the Constitution and is constitutionally valid.

anchor.surface_text: This section on its own plain reading taken within its fold all the objectionable matters which had been taken by sub- Art.  2  of Art. 19 out of the guaranteed freedom of speech and expression Protected by cl.  a  of Art. 19 1 .

holdings.reasoning_summary: Plain reading of s.9 encompasses matters excluded by Art.19(2); 'tends to overthrow the State' falls under security of State.

holdings.text: Article 19(2) saves the constitutional validity of Section 9 of the Act.

anchor.surface_text: Article 19 2  thus saves the companystitutional validity of 9 of the Act. The analogy between s. 124A, I.P.C. and s. 9 of the Act is wholly misconceived

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.9 imposes reasonable restrictions matching Art.19(2) grounds like security of State, public order; balances individual right with social interests.

holdings.text: Section 3 of U.P. Special Powers Act materially different from s.9; its invalidation no precedent for s.9.

anchor.surface_text: On the face of its plain language this section is materially different from s. 9 of the Act. It therefore does number require. elaborate argu-  1  1962 2 S.C.R. 321. ment for distinguishing this decision.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No similarity between provisions; s.3 not savable by Art.19(2), unlike s.9.

holdings.text: Analogy between s.124A IPC (as in Kedarnath) and s.9 misconceived; no narrow construction limiting s.9 to incitement to violence.

anchor.surface_text: The analogy between s. 124A, I.P.C. and s. 9 of the Act is wholly misconceived and in view of the companyprehensive of Art. 19 2  we are unable to restrict s. 9 of the Act only to those speeches and Expressions which. incite or tend to incite Violence

holdings.reasoning_summary: Comprehensive scope of Art.19(2) does not warrant restricting s.9 like sedition; reasonableness context-specific.

holdings.text: Impugned High Court judgment shows no serious legal infirmity warranting interference under Art.136.

anchor.surface_text: The impugned judgment of the High Court does number show any serious legal infirmity resulting in failure, of justice which should induce this Court to interfere under Art. 136 of the Constitution.

holdings.reasoning_summary: No grave injustice or legal error; interlocutory order; scope of special leave appeal not enlarged to merits.

holdings.text: Charge not to be quashed; no interference with lower courts' prima facie finding of offence under s.9.

anchor.surface_text: We are unable find any such infirmity in the impugned judgment. The additional factor against our interference in this case in the interlocutory character of the order sought to be quashed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Sessions and High Court correctly refused quash; trial court to decide merits without influence from observations.

holdings.text: Supreme Court will not construe speech or decide legality of charge framing at interlocutory appeal stage.

anchor.surface_text: Shri Agarwal made a strenuous effort to persuade us to companys- true the offending portion of the speech as reproduced in the judgment of the High Court and express our opinion whether- or number the charge against him has been lawfully framed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Interlocutory; for trial magistrate; Art.136 limited to serious infirmity, not merits review.

anchor.surface_text: This appeal fails and is dismissed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Cumulative: validity upheld, no grounds for interference.
